author: HCAndersen
text: "My poor flowers are quite dead," said little Ida, "they were so pretty yesterday evening, and now all the leaves are hanging down quite withered.

author: HCAndersen
text: What do they do that for," she asked, of the student who sat on the sofa; she liked him very much, he could tell the most amusing stories, and cut out the prettiest pictures; hearts, and ladies dancing, castles with doors that opened, as well as flowers; he was a delightful student.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Why do the flowers look so faded to-day?" she asked again, and pointed to her nosegay, which was quite withered.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Don't you know what is the matter with them?" said the student.

author: HCAndersen
text: "The flowers were at a ball last night, and therefore, it is no wonder they hang their heads."

author: HCAndersen
text: "But flowers cannot dance?" cried little Ida.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes indeed, they can," replied the student.

author: HCAndersen
text: "When it grows dark, and everybody is asleep, they jump about quite merrily.

author: HCAndersen
text: They have a ball almost every night."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Can children go to these balls?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes," said the student, "little daisies and lilies of the valley."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Where do the beautiful flowers dance?" asked little Ida.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Have you not often seen the large castle outside the gates of the town, where the king lives in summer, and where the beautiful garden is full of flowers?

author: HCAndersen
text: And have you not fed the swans with bread when they swam towards you?

author: HCAndersen
text: Well, the flowers have capital balls there, believe me."

author: HCAndersen
text: "I was in the garden out there yesterday with my mother," said Ida, "but all the leaves were off the trees, and there was not a single flower left.

author: HCAndersen
text: Where are they?

author: HCAndersen
text: I used to see so many in the summer."

author: HCAndersen
text: "They are in the castle," replied the student.

author: HCAndersen
text: "You must know that as soon as the king and all the court are gone into the town, the flowers run out of the garden into the castle, and you should see how merry they are.

author: HCAndersen
text: The two most beautiful roses seat themselves on the throne, and are called the king and queen, then all the red cockscombs range themselves on each side, and bow, these are the lords-in-waiting.

author: HCAndersen
text: After that the pretty flowers come in, and there is a grand ball.

author: HCAndersen
text: The blue violets represent little naval cadets, and dance with hyacinths and crocuses which they call young ladies.

author: HCAndersen
text: The tulips and tiger-lilies are the old ladies who sit and watch the dancing, so that everything may be conducted with order and propriety."

author: HCAndersen
text: "But," said little Ida, "is there no one there to hurt the flowers for dancing in the king's castle?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "No one knows anything about it," said the student.

author: HCAndersen
text: "The old steward of the castle, who has to watch there at night, sometimes comes in; but he carries a great bunch of keys, and as soon as the flowers hear the keys rattle, they run and hide themselves behind the long curtains, and stand quite still, just peeping their heads out.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the old steward says, 'I smell flowers here,' but he cannot see them."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh how capital," said little Ida, clapping her hands.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Should I be able to see these flowers?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes," said the student, "mind you think of it the next time you go out, no doubt you will see them, if you peep through the window.

author: HCAndersen
text: I did so to-day, and I saw a long yellow lily lying stretched out on the sofa.

author: HCAndersen
text: She was a court lady."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Can the flowers from the Botanical Gardens go to these balls?" asked Ida.

author: HCAndersen
text: "It is such a distance!"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh yes," said the student 'whenever they like, for they can fly.

author: HCAndersen
text: Have you not seen those beautiful red, white. and yellow butterflies, that look like flowers?

author: HCAndersen
text: They were flowers once.

author: HCAndersen
text: They have flown off their stalks into the air, and flap their leaves as if they were little wings to make them fly.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then, if they behave well, they obtain permission to fly about during the day, instead of being obliged to sit still on their stems at home, and so in time their leaves become real wings.

author: HCAndersen
text: It may be, however, that the flowers in the Botanical Gardens have never been to the king's palace, and, therefore, they know nothing of the merry doings at night, which take place there.

author: HCAndersen
text: I will tell you what to do, and the botanical professor, who lives close by here, will be so surprised.

author: HCAndersen
text: You know him very well, do you not?

author: HCAndersen
text: Well, next time you go into his garden, you must tell one of the flowers that there is going to be a grand ball at the castle, then that flower will tell all the others, and they will fly away to the castle as soon as possible.

author: HCAndersen
text: And when the professor walks into his garden, there will not be a single flower left.

author: HCAndersen
text: How he will wonder what has become of them!"

author: HCAndersen
text: "But how can one flower tell another?

author: HCAndersen
text: Flowers cannot speak?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "No, certainly not," replied the student; "but they can make signs.

author: HCAndersen
text: Have you not often seen that when the wind blows they nod at one another, and rustle all their green leaves?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Can the professor understand the signs?" asked Ida.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes, to be sure he can.

author: HCAndersen
text: He went one morning into his garden, and saw a stinging nettle making signs with its leaves to a beautiful red carnation.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was saying, 'You are so pretty, I like you very much.'

author: HCAndersen
text: But the professor did not approve of such nonsense, so he clapped his hands on the nettle to stop it.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the leaves, which are its fingers, stung him so sharply that he has never ventured to touch a nettle since."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh how funny!" said Ida, and she laughed.

author: HCAndersen
text: "How can anyone put such notions into a child's head?" said a tiresome lawyer, who had come to pay a visit, and sat on the sofa.

author: HCAndersen
text: He did not like the student, and would grumble when he saw him cutting out droll or amusing pictures.

author: HCAndersen
text: Sometimes it would be a man hanging on a gibbet and holding a heart in his hand as if he had been stealing hearts.

author: HCAndersen
text: Sometimes it was an old witch riding through the air on a broom and carrying her husband on her nose.

author: HCAndersen
text: But the lawyer did not like such jokes, and he would say as he had just said, "How can anyone put such nonsense into a child's head! what absurd fancies there are!"

author: HCAndersen
text: But to little Ida, all these stories which the student told her about the flowers, seemed very droll, and she thought over them a great deal.

author: HCAndersen
text: The flowers did hang their heads, because they had been dancing all night, and were very tired, and most likely they were ill.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then she took them into the room where a number of toys lay on a pretty little table, and the whole of the table drawer besides was full of beautiful things.

author: HCAndersen
text: Her doll Sophy lay in the doll's bed asleep, and little Ida said to her, "You must really get up Sophy, and be content to lie in the drawer to-night; the poor flowers are ill, and they must lie in your bed, then perhaps they will get well again."

author: HCAndersen
text: So she took the doll out, who looked quite cross, and said not a single word, for she was angry at being turned out of her bed.

author: HCAndersen
text: Ida placed the flowers in the doll's bed, and drew the quilt over them.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then she told them to lie quite still and be good, while she made some tea for them, so that they might be quite well and able to get up the next morning.

author: HCAndersen
text: And she drew the curtains close round the little bed, so that the sun might not shine in their eyes.

author: HCAndersen
text: During the whole evening she could not help thinking of what the student had told her.

author: HCAndersen
text: And before she went to bed herself, she was obliged to peep behind the curtains into the garden where all her mother's beautiful flowers grew, hyacinths and tulips, and many others.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then she whispered to them quite softly, "I know you are going to a ball to-night."

author: HCAndersen
text: But the flowers appeared as if they did not understand, and not a leaf moved; still Ida felt quite sure she knew all about it.

author: HCAndersen
text: She lay awake a long time after she was in bed, thinking how pretty it must be to see all the beautiful flowers dancing in the king's garden.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I wonder if my flowers have really been there," she said to herself, and then she fell asleep.

author: HCAndersen
text: In the night she awoke; she had been dreaming of the flowers and of the student, as well as of the tiresome lawyer who found fault with him.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was quite still in Ida's bedroom; the night-lamp burnt on the table, and her father and mother were asleep.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I wonder if my flowers are still lying in Sophy's bed," she thought to herself; "how much I should like to know."

author: HCAndersen
text: She raised herself a little, and glanced at the door of the room where all her flowers and playthings lay; it was partly open, and as she listened, it seemed as if some one in the room was playing the piano, but softly and more prettily than she had ever before heard it.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Now all the flowers are certainly dancing in there," she thought, "oh how much I should like to see them," but she did not dare move for fear of disturbing her father and mother.

author: HCAndersen
text: "If they would only come in here," she thought; but they did not come, and the music continued to play so beautifully, and was so pretty, that she could resist no longer.

author: HCAndersen
text: She crept out of her little bed, went softly to the door and looked into the room.

author: HCAndersen
text: Oh what a splendid sight there was to be sure!

author: HCAndersen
text: There was no night-lamp burning, but the room appeared quite light, for the moon shone through the window upon the floor, and made it almost like day.

author: HCAndersen
text: All the hyacinths and tulips stood in two long rows down the room, not a single flower remained in the window, and the flower-pots were all empty.

author: HCAndersen
text: The flowers were dancing gracefully on the floor, making turns and holding each other by their long green leaves as they swung round.

author: HCAndersen
text: At the piano sat a large yellow lily which little Ida was sure she had seen in the summer, for she remembered the student saying she was very much like Miss Lina, one of Ida's friends.

author: HCAndersen
text: They all laughed at him then, but now it seemed to little Ida as if the tall, yellow flower was really like the young lady.

author: HCAndersen
text: She had just the same manners while playing, bending her long yellow face from side to side, and nodding in time to the beautiful music.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then she saw a large purple crocus jump into the middle of the table where the playthings stood, go up to the doll's bedstead and draw back the curtains; there lay the sick flowers, but they got up directly, and nodded to the others as a sign that they wished to dance with them.

author: HCAndersen
text: The old rough doll, with the broken mouth, stood up and bowed to the pretty flowers.

author: HCAndersen
text: They did not look ill at all now, but jumped about and were very merry, yet none of them noticed little Ida.

author: HCAndersen
text: Presently it seemed as if something fell from the table.

author: HCAndersen
text: Ida looked that way, and saw a slight carnival rod jumping down among the flowers as if it belonged to them; it was, however, very smooth and neat, and a little wax doll with a broad brimmed hat on her head, like the one worn by the lawyer, sat upon it.

author: HCAndersen
text: The carnival rod hopped about among the flowers on its three red stilted feet, and stamped quite loud when it danced the Mazurka; the flowers could not perform this dance, they were too light to stamp in that manner.

author: HCAndersen
text: All at once the wax doll which rode on the carnival rod seemed to grow larger and taller, and it turned round and said to the paper flowers, "How can you put such things in a child's head? they are all foolish fancies;" and then the doll was exactly like the lawyer with the broad brimmed hat, and looked as yellow and as cross as he did; but the paper dolls struck him on his thin legs, and he shrunk up again and became quite a little wax doll.

author: HCAndersen
text: This was very amusing, and Ida could not help laughing.

author: HCAndersen
text: The carnival rod went on dancing, and the lawyer was obliged to dance also.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was no use, he might make himself great and tall, or remain a little wax doll with a large black hat; still he must dance.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then at last the other flowers interceded for him, especially those who had lain in the doll's bed, and the carnival rod gave up his dancing.

author: HCAndersen
text: At the same moment a loud knocking was heard in the drawer, where Ida's doll Sophy lay with many other toys.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the rough doll ran to the end of the table, laid himself flat down upon it, and began to pull the drawer out a little way.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then Sophy raised himself, and looked round quite astonished, "There must be a ball here to-night," said Sophy.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Why did not somebody tell me?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Will you dance with me?" said the rough doll.

author: HCAndersen
text: "You are the right sort to dance with, certainly," said she, turning her back upon him.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then she seated herself on the edge of the drawer, and thought that perhaps one of the flowers would ask her to dance; but none of them came.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then she coughed, "Hem, hem, a-hem;" but for all that not one came.

author: HCAndersen
text: The shabby doll now danced quite alone, and not very badly, after all.

author: HCAndersen
text: As none of the flowers seemed to notice Sophy, she let herself down from the drawer to the floor, so as to make a very great noise.

author: HCAndersen
text: All the flowers came round her directly, and asked if she had hurt herself, especially those who had lain in her bed.

author: HCAndersen
text: But she was not hurt at all, and Ida's flowers thanked her for the use of the nice bed, and were very kind to her.

author: HCAndersen
text: They led her into the middle of the room, where the moon shone, and danced with her, while all the other flowers formed a circle round them.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then Sophy was very happy, and said they might keep her bed; she did not mind lying in the drawer at all.

author: HCAndersen
text: But the flowers thanked her very much, and said,- "We cannot live long.

author: HCAndersen
text: To-morrow morning we shall be quite dead; and you must tell little Ida to bury us in the garden, near to the grave of the canary; then, in the summer we shall wake up and be more beautiful than ever."

author: HCAndersen
text: "No, you must not die," said Sophy, as she kissed the flowers.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the door of the room opened, and a number of beautiful flowers danced in.

author: HCAndersen
text: Ida could not imagine where they could come from, unless they were the flowers from the king's garden.

author: HCAndersen
text: First came two lovely roses, with little golden crowns on their heads; these were the king and queen.

author: HCAndersen
text: Beautiful stocks and carnations followed, bowing to every one present.

author: HCAndersen
text: They had also music with them.

author: HCAndersen
text: Large poppies and peonies had pea-shells for instruments, and blew into them till they were quite red in the face.

author: HCAndersen
text: The bunches of blue hyacinths and the little white snowdrops jingled their bell-like flowers, as if they were real bells.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then came many more flowers: blue violets, purple heart's-ease, daisies, and lilies of the valley, and they all danced together, and kissed each other.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was very beautiful to behold.

author: HCAndersen
text: At last the flowers wished each other good-night.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then little Ida crept back into her bed again, and dreamt of all she had seen.

author: HCAndersen
text: When she arose the next morning, she went quickly to the little table, to see if the flowers were still there.

author: HCAndersen
text: She drew aside the curtains of the little bed.

author: HCAndersen
text: There they all lay, but quite faded; much more so than the day before.

author: HCAndersen
text: Sophy was lying in the drawer where Ida had placed her; but she looked very sleepy.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Do you remember what the flowers told you to say to me?" said little Ida.

author: HCAndersen
text: But Sophy looked quite stupid, and said not a single word.

author: HCAndersen
text: "You are not kind at all," said Ida; "and yet they all danced with you."

author: HCAndersen
text: Then she took a little paper box, on which were painted beautiful birds, and laid the dead flowers in it.

author: HCAndersen
text: "This shall be your pretty coffin," she said; "and by and by, when my cousins come to visit me, they shall help me to bury you out in the garden; so that next summer you may grow up again more beautiful than ever."

author: HCAndersen
text: Her cousins were two good-tempered boys, whose names were James and Adolphus.

author: HCAndersen
text: Their father had given them each a bow and arrow, and they had brought them to show Ida.

author: HCAndersen
text: She told them about the poor flowers which were dead; and as soon as they obtained permission, they went with her to bury them.

author: HCAndersen
text: The two boys walked first, with their crossbows on their shoulders, and little Ida followed, carrying the pretty box containing the dead flowers.

author: HCAndersen
text: They dug a little grave in the garden.

author: HCAndersen
text: Ida kissed her flowers and then laid them, with the box, in the earth.

author: HCAndersen
text: James and Adolphus then fired their crossbows over the grave, as they had neither guns nor cannons.
